Context:
The text provides information about a three-year advanced behavioral science technology program offered by an unspecified college. Students who complete this program will undergo a bridge semester (January - April), followed by an unpaid internship (September - December), and finish with the final term, Semester 8 (January - April). The primary focus of the program is Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA), which is a scientific approach to understanding and modifying human behavior.

ABA is used to treat various populations, including individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), brain injury, dementia, developmental disabilities, addiction, and mental health disorders. Students will gain comprehensive knowledge of behavioral psychology and ABA throughout the program.

The program consists of three main components:
1. Conducting a complete behavioral assessment.
2. Developing an effective plan based on the assessment results.
3. Ongoing evaluation of the first two components.

Students will also be required to undertake a research component, which includes preparing an Applied Research Proposal prior to conducting their research during the fall internship (September - December) and writing a research thesis before graduating. The Association for Behaviour Analysis International has verified specific courses in the program towards its coursework requirements.

No factual information related to college name, contact details, or any other specific entities have been provided in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis Program (Year 4 Bridge) S304 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Association for Behavior Analysis International (ABAI) has verified the following courses towards the requirements for taking the Board Certified Behaviour Analyst® or Board Certified Assistant Behaviour Analyst® examination:
- Behavioural science theories, principles and methods
- Special populations
- Psychology
- Research methods/statistics
- Ethics, professionalism and leadership

The degree program helps prepare students to become leaders in behaviour analysis by providing opportunities to learn from a system-wide perspective and support large-scale changes in agencies, organizations, and government. Graduates have become leaders in fields such as forensic mental health, autism spectrum disorder, and acquired brain injury.

The field education options include a 14-week unpaid field experience term during which students conduct a research thesis. Students will receive support from the agency on-site supervisor and college faculty field liaison.

Career options for ABA practitioners include assessment of clients' skills, development and implementation of skill acquisition programs, and functional assessment of challenging behaviours.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis Program (Year 4 Bridge) S304 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text discusses various skills and knowledge areas related to Behaviour Analysis and its applications, which include assessing clients' skills, developing skill acquisition programs, functional assessment of challenging behaviours, behaviour management plans, data collection and analysis, case management, and numerous job titles such as autism spectrum disorders consultant, behaviour technician, behaviour therapist, behavioural consultant, behavioural specialist, instructor therapist, recreational therapist, residential support worker, transition co-ordinator, and vocational support worker.

Graduates of an Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis program have furthered their education at institutions like Brock University (Applied Disability Studies), The Chicago School of Professional Psychology (Applied Behavior Analysis), Missouri State University (Applied Behavior Analysis), Western University (Applied Behaviour Analysis), and University of British Columbia (Special Education) or Yorkville University (Master of Arts in Counselling Psychology).

Additionally, the text mentions a postgraduate certificate named "Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care (S417)" which is a two-semester program where students will learn to coordinate and manage an interprofessional healthcare team of complex and long-term care professionals. It is delivered online and on-demand, and includes a clinical field placement component. The required courses for this program include BEHA 2106, Advanced Research Design and Statistics; BEHA 2107, Advanced Assessment Strategies and Behaviour Theory; BEHA 3101, Clinical Behaviour Analysis; BEHA 4002, Behavioural Approaches to Health and Well-Being; BEHA 4001, Organizational Behaviour Management; BEHA 4003, Service Delivery and Interprofessional Practice; BEHA 4106, Applied Thesis Development Seminar; BEHA 4107, Applied Thesis Project Seminar; Liberal Studies Elective; and BEHA 4000 - Work Experience, a 14-week field experience term (unpaid).

Context:
Program Information:
- Semester 8 of the BEHA (Behavioural Science) program
- Courses offered: BEHA 4101 to BEHA 4105, Thesis (42 hours), Liberal Studies Elective
- Learning Outcomes:
  - Understand psychological theory, research and practices
  - Design and conduct assessments across various settings and populations
  - Implement research-based programs in Applied Behaviour Analysis
  - Practise behavioural consulting skills with different populations
  - Demonstrate professionalism, ethical standards and social skills
  - Communicate results of behavioural assessments and treatment programs
  - Critically evaluate and synthesize societal issues

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic tuition for the first two semesters starting Fall 2023: $7,150.00 *
- Estimated total fees (tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees) for the first two semesters starting Fall 2024: [Amounts not provided] **
- Tuition fees do NOT include Field Experience or Work Term costs

Financial Assistance:
- Approved for OSAP funding if applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria

* Amounts are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates.
** Tuition fees are subject to board approval, while material, student service and ancillary fees are estimated based on prior years. All fees are subject to change without notice.

Context:
Extracted Information:

1. Students are required to verify George Brown College fee requirements.
2. Admission Requirements:
   - Successful completion of a three-year Behavioural Science Technology advanced diploma program or equivalent, with a minimum program GPA of 3.0.
   - English language proficiency: George Brown College ESL Level 9; TOEFL 84 overall and 21 in each skill band (online); IELTS 6.5 overall and 6.0 in each skill band; MELAB 85; CAEL overall 70 (writing 60).
   - Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions. Visit the Transfer Guide for more information.
3. George Brown College has been granted a consent by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities to offer this applied degree for a seven-year term starting July 21, 2015.
4. Students must meet and complete all mandatory Pre-placement requirements for this program. It will take up to 8 to 10 weeks to complete.
   - Proof of medical records (TDAP shot, MMR, Varicella, Hep B blood test reports/titres, Two-Step TB Skin Test) and a clear Vulnerable Sector Check renewed every year must be submitted by the program specific deadline to ParaMed Placement Pass website.
5. COVID-19 vaccination: Students who are not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 may not be able to complete the required field placement component of their program in the regularly scheduled time frame.
6. Students who do not comply with the program’s health policy and non-academic requirements, or who do not submit all required documentation by deadlines established by the program will be excluded from the clinical practicum.

Context:
* Students must submit all required documentation by established deadlines to avoid exclusion from clinical practicum.
* Exclusion from clinical practicum may jeopardize academic standing and successful completion of the program.
* All costs, service fees, and fines associated with health requirements are the responsibility of students.
* Students must complete a Pre-placement health form and renew it every year for clinical placements.
* Vulnerable Sector Check is required for all students in the program.
* The process for obtaining a Vulnerable Sector Check can take 2-3 months, but may take up to 8 months under certain circumstances.
* Students are responsible for ensuring that their Vulnerable Sector Check covers appropriateness for working with vulnerable persons.
* Students must keep the original copy of their Vulnernerable Sector Check.
* Students who cannot provide a "clear" vulnerable sector check may not be able to start field or clinical placements and may jeopardize their progress in the program.
* Failure to meet requirements for field placement can prevent students from completing the program and securing employment.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
* For more information, contact the School of Health and Wellness at 416-415-5000 ext. 4542 or email [yansang.feng@georgebrown.ca](mailto:yansang.feng@georgebrown.ca)
* For more information about the program, contact the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
* Related programs include Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S302).
